awd_titl_txt: Synthetic Receptor-Based Arrays for Sensing Post-Translationally Modified Proteins and Peptides
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Wenwan Zhong and her group at the University of California - Riverside are working to improve our fundamental understanding of how proteins work.  Proteins are the workhorses of all living systems.  Their functions are regulated by diverse modifications of protein structures.  Identifying and understanding these modifications can benefit many areas of research, including such diverse work as probing the chemical mechanisms of life, energy production, and environmental remediation. The Zhong group seeks to enhance this knowledge by developing selective recognition tools that can accurately assess changes in protein modification in response to external stimulation of living cells. Specifically, they are developing a series of sensors for specific types of protein modification. The recognition element is a judiciously designed molecule that acts like a lock's "keyhole," fitting only a correctly sized "key" - the right type of modification on a protein. Inserting the "key" into the "lock" generates a large optical signal, allowing simple and rapid detection of protein modifications. The work targets improved understanding of protein modification, thereby advancing strategies for controlling processes in living systems. In addition to these technical impacts, the work is enhancing the diversity of the scientific workforce via engagement of both graduate and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups. 

The Zhong group is developing synthetic receptor-based arrays for detection of post-translational modifications (PTMs) in proteins. Selective host-guest interactions between modified side chains and synthetic receptors (cavitands) allows highly selective recognition of modified proteins, and can discriminate for example among proteins with different methylation levels, sites, and numbers. The technique will be valuable in rapid profiling of methylation alterations in cells under external stimulation and in situ monitoring of PTM enzyme activities. Initial targets include hosts that bind selectively to trimethylated lysine, with an aim of enabling array-based PTM profiling. Cavitand hosts are being synthesized and used in fluorescence displacement assays (FDA) for selective detection and discrimination of PTM peptides. Characterization of cavitand-guest interactions will enhance understanding of how cavitand structures affect binding strength and kinetics, supporting new designs with improved FDA performance. In a specific model application, cavitand-based arrays are being applied to study histone methylation in stimulated cells. It is expected that the highly selective and versatile PTM sensing arrays enabled by cavitands can greatly improve the detection of peptides carrying modifications, and enhance the efficacy of PTM study. Discovery of hosts with high affinity and selectivity for diverse PTM types will boost understanding of PTM functions.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
Overview. Synthetic receptors represent a complementary, yet powerful alternative to bio-macromolecules for target recognition in bioanalysis, providing the advantages of tunable structural design, and low cost and high scalability in production. They have been extensively employed in molecular detection, by coupling the non-covalent host-guest interactions with a signal (often optical) output. Multiple receptors can also form the so-called “chemical nose/tongue” sensor platform for differential sensing. However, they face the challenges of “pan” selectivity and limited scope of targets directly recognizable by the receptors. In this project supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry at NSF, we developed numerous cavitand-based arrays for detection of diverse targets that range from small ions, drugs of abuse, peptides with post-translational modifications (PTMs), to folded nucleic acids. Our work not only produces synthetic receptor-based sensing arrays as useful analytical tools in molecular measurements, which can function in complex environments, but also provides mechanistic understanding on how structural variations in hosts affect guest binding and how alternative sensing mechanisms can occur. The knowledge gained from this work will guide the future design of cavitand-based detectors for diverse target analytes.

Intellectual Merit. This project produced a library of new cavitand structures and new fluorescent guests for both mechanistic study and for sensor array construction. These new cavitands and guests have expanded the capability of the cavitand-based arrays in sensing via multiple sensing mechanisms. The cavitands bind suitably sized substrates with soft layers of positive charge, most notably the trimethylammonium group present in trimethyllysine. Direct displacement of fluorescent guests from the cavity was exploited to recognize lysine residues in modified peptides, and used to measure methyltransferase activity, as well as assist PTM separations. The hosts can also exploit indirect sensing mechanisms to expand the scope of analytes detectible by our arrays. We established arrays for sensing small analytes like heavy metal ions, anionic halides, steroids, low-molecular-weight thiols, small phosphosugars, cannabinoids and their key metabolites, as well as chiral insect pheromones. In addition, we designed arrays to target non-methylation PTMs, including citrulline modification and phosphorylation. Furthermore, we challenged our array to differentiate macromolecules with small structural differences, like immunoglobulin isoforms, DNA folded structures, and the folded DNAs with chemically modified nucleosides. Better understanding of molecular recognition properties of deep cavitands in biological environments were gained by investigating recognition using techniques like NMR, Isothermal Titration Calorimetry (ITC), optical spectroscopy, and capillary electrophoresis (CE). We also studied host-guest interaction complex environments such as serum, saliva, urine and lipid membranes. Most intriguing, we explored host-guest interaction in cellular environment and observed that selective interactions and guest displacement occurred in cells.

Besides sensing array developments, we employed various machine learning approaches to enhance differentiation accuracy and help with subjective selection of optimal sensor elements to selectively focus on different analytes. The knowledge gained from our work can help guide future array design and data analysis to deal with the ever growing receptor and dye libraries and diverse types of targets.

During the entire award period, we published 21 papers, illustrating the power of host-guest arrays in sensing diverse biorelevant targets. Our research program is inherently multi-disciplinary, bringing together chemistry, biology, and materials science. The ability to selectively detect and analyze modified peptides as well as folded nucleic acids is also important in the field of epigenetics, and will provide an understanding of the mechanisms of cellular control.

Broader impacts. The broader impacts of our work can be illustrated in two aspects: dissemination of our research outcomes, and student or postdoc education. In this NSF grant, 1 postdoc, 16 graduate students, and 6 undergraduate students have been trained in a variety of techniques in synthetic organic and analytical chemistry. The work has been disseminated by both PIs via presentations at conferences and invited talks at universities, as well as organization of a symposium devoted to supramolecular sensing. Both PIs are committed to supporting undergraduate research and minority participation: several papers were published with undergraduate co-authors in support of the grant. PI Zhong was awarded the 2019 UC Riverside Chancellor’s Award for Fostering Excellence in Undergraduate Research, and Co-PI Hooley was the recipient of the 2023 UC Riverside Distinguished Teaching Award. In addition, we have contributed to curriculum development, focusing on increasing retention of under-represented groups in introductory large enrollment chemistry lectures and labs at UC Riverside, a Minority Serving Institution. Our students also perform demonstrations at local high schools, and the PIs collaborate with local Public Undergraduate Institutes and supervise local high school students in conducting research.

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2023
Modified by: Wenwan Zhong
